docs.lead_paragraph: It is no surprise that some restaurant, tavern and package-store owners are lobbying against a bill that would require them to post signs warning pregnant women of the dangers of alcohol consumption. But the proposal's supporters did not expect the battle to be joined by the state chapter of the National Organization for Women, which is arguing that the bill unfairly singles out women and would send a message that the rights of the fetus exceeded those of the woman carrying it.

headline.main: Unlikely Union in Albany: Feminists and Liquor Sellers

byline.original: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A Michigan appeals court today ruled that a women should not stand trial on charges of delivering cocaine to her newborn son through the umbilical cord in a case that civil libertarians said could set the tone for future cases involving pregnant women who abuse drugs. In a unanimous decision, the Michigan Court of Appeals rejected the state's argument that Kimberly Hardy, a 24-year-old unemployed factory worker from Muskegon, passed cocaine to her son Areanis in a way that constituted criminal delivery of drugs. The charge arose from Ms. Hardy's use of crack just hours before her son's birth.

headline.main: Woman Cleared After Drug Use in Pregnancy

byline.original: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-9 About 20,000 U.S. troops will leave southern Iraq starting in two weeks. Officials said the Iraqi military was so devastated that a large force was no longer needed. Page A1
